guideline.name: Annotation of DPWG Guideline for quetiapine and CYP3A4

implications.html: The plasma concentration of quetiapine is 3.2-fold higher in these patients. In addition, the formation of the active metabolite N-desalkylquetiapine, which is probably responsible for the antidepressant effect, should be reduced. The gene variation results in reduced activity of the enzyme CYP3A4, which converts quetiapine to N-desalkylquetiapine and an inactive metabolite.

recommendation.html:
Indication DEPRESSION: Choose an alternative. Aripiprazole appears to be less dependent of CYP3A4 for metabolism. Olanzapine is not metabolised by CYP3A4.
 
OTHER INDICATIONS: Use 30% of the standard dose.

guideline.name: Annotation of DPWG Guideline for quetiapine and CYP3A4

implications.html: This gene variation reduces the conversion of quetiapine to inactive metabolites and a metabolite with anti-depressant effect. However, the effect on the plasma concentration of quetiapine is limited (20% increase) and it is not known whether this has any clinical consequences. The relationship between the plasma concentration and clinical effect is weak for quetiapine.

recommendation.html: NO action is needed for this gene-drug interaction.

guideline.name: Annotation of DPWG Guideline for quetiapine and CYP3A4

implications.html: The guideline does not provide a description of the impact of a normal metabolizer phenotype on quetiapine.

recommendation.html: The guideline does not provide a recommendation for quetiapine in normal metabolizers.

guideline.name: Annotation of DPWG Guideline for quetiapine and CYP3A4

gene.name: cytochrome P450 family 3 subfamily A member 4

synonym: cytochrome P450, family 3, subfamily A, polypeptide 4

terms.term: oxidoreductase activity, acting on paired donors, with incorporation or reduction of molecular oxygen, reduced flavin or flavoprotein as one donor, and incorporation of one atom of oxygen

history.description: Annotation current with May 2021 DPWG Guideline release
Updated annotation based on February 2022 release and added extended dosing guideline
Updated link to testing guidance page
Annotation current with February 2022 DPWG guideline release

relatedGenes.name: cytochrome P450 family 3 subfamily A member 4

summaryMarkdown.html: Patients who are CYP3A4 poor metabolizers and being treated for depression should be given an alternative drug. Patients being treated for other indications and who are CYP3A4 poor metabolizers should be given a reduced dose of quetiapine. No action is needed for patients who are CYP3A4 intermediate metabolizers.

textMarkdown.html:
February 2022 Update

The Royal Dutch Pharmacists Association - Pharmacogenetics Working Group has updated their therapeutic dose recommendations for quetiapine based on CYP3A4 genotypes. They now recommend an alternative drug for patients who are CYP3A4 poor metabolizers (PMs) who are being treated for depression. A dose reduction is recommended for patients who are CYP3A4 PMs and being treated for other indications.

Wording in table taken from the Dutch guidelines February 2022 update.

Allele/Genotype/Phenotype Drug Description Recommendation
CYP3A4 IM quetiapine This gene variation reduces the conversion of quetiapine to inactive metabolites and a metabolite with anti-depressant effect. However, the effect on the plasma concentration of quetiapine is limited (20% increase) and it is not known whether this has any clinical consequences. The relationship between the plasma concentration and clinical effect is weak for quetiapine. NO action is needed for this gene-drug interaction.
CYP3A4 PM quetiapine The plasma concentration of quetiapine is 3.2-fold higher in these patients. In addition, the formation of the active metabolite N-desalkylquetiapine, which is probably responsible for the antidepressant effect, should be reduced. The gene variation results in reduced activity of the enzyme CYP3A4, which converts quetiapine to N-desalkylquetiapine and an inactive metabolite. Indication DEPRESSION: choose an alternative.
Aripiprazole appears to be less dependent on CYP3A4 for metabolism. Olanzapine is not metabolised by CYP3A4.
OTHER INDICATIONS: use 30% of the standard dose.

Preemptive genotyping

Excerpts from the DPWG risk analysis document for quetiapine and CYP3A4:

The KNMP Pharmacogenetics Working Group considers genotyping before starting quetiapine to be potentially beneficial for prevention of adverse events and for effectiveness. Genotyping can be considered on an individual patient basis. If, however, the genotype is available, the KNMP Pharmacogenetics Working Group recommends adhering to the gene-drug guideline.

Read more about how DPWG assigns their recommendations for preemptive genotyping.

Read for more information about this recommendation, Read about gene information from DPWG

May 2021 Guideline

The Royal Dutch Pharmacists Association - Pharmacogenetics Working Group has evaluated therapeutic dose recommendations for quetiapine based on CYP3A4 genotypes. They conclude that this is not a gene-drug interaction (see Dutch guidelines May 2021 update).

Read for more information about this recommendation, Read about gene information from DPWG
